title: Grow Your Own Grains Part 1: Best Seeding Methods -- Low Tech Video No. 24

tasks.task: Planting oats, barley, and field peas in a prepared field
subtasks: Using a tiller to disk the top soil inch or two deep, crushing weeds
Spreading horse manure compost over the field
Tilling the field to incorporate the manure into the soil
Setting up rows for planting at eight-inch intervals using stakes
Selecting the correct disc size for a single-row seeder to achieve desired seeding rate
Loading seeds into the seeder and rotating the disc to count the number of seeds released
Modifying the seeder disc with tape to adjust the seeding rate as needed
Planting the seeds at a depth of three-quarters to one inch by walking the rows and sowing the seeds
Ensuring even coverage and adjusting the seeding rate through testing and modification
Broadcasting field peas, which are legumes fixing nitrogen, without additional fertilizer
Weeding the planted area by knocking down emerged weeds and allowing the cereal crops to outcompete subsequent weeds
Experimenting with different seeding rates using a broadcast method for oats if a seeder is not available

tasks.task: Planting oats, barley, and field peas in prepared soil.
Planting oats, barley, and field peas in a prepared field.
subtasks: Disking the topsoil with a tiller to control weeds.
Spreading horse manure over the field.
Tilling the manure into the soil to enrich the planting area.
Marking rows for planting using stakes spaced eight inches apart.
Setting up the single-row seeder to achieve an appropriate seeding rate for each grain (e.g., 10 seeds per foot with eight-inch spacing, modified via disc covers).
Modifying a single-row seeder by covering half of the discs with tape to reduce the number of seeds released per pass, in order to achieve the desired seeding rate lower than the factory setting.

Calculating the required number of seeds per pass of the seeder by placing seeds into a disc, rotating the disc a full circle, counting the seeds, and modifying the disc configuration (covering every other hole with tape) to adjust the count from around 80 to the desired seeding rate of roughly 10 seeds per foot (with eight-inch spacing).
Planting rows eight inches apart to facilitate weeding and maximize spacing for the grains.
Allow the planted cereal grains to outgrow and shade out weeds that naturally grow in the field.
Planting field peas with no additional fertilizer, relying on their ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen into the soil.
